Name: Birdman
Review: the acting was phenomenal, ditto the soundtrack, but for whatever reason the other parts just stuck me as "pretty good"

Name: 10 Cloverfield Lane
Review: did this really need to become part of a franchise?

Name: Stage Fright
Review: fun and surprisingly funny? my knowledge of Hitchcock is sorely limited to the big names (Psycho, the Birds, Vertigo, etc) so this was a lovely surprise. the acting is on-point -- Jane Wyman and Michael Wilding are charming as all get-out, and Alastair Sim is a delight to watch.

Name: All the President's Men
Review: gripping pacing and fantastic camerawork throughout. calls for a rewatch solely for the amount of information that's crammed into 2 hours. the final few minutes feel rushed / tacked on and I wonder what a 3 hour version would have felt like.

Name: Treasure of the Four Crowns
Review: italian indiana jones as a heist movie. 3d effects are abundant. a whole lot of fun, but I wonder how it plays in 2d?

Name: Hit the Road Running
Review: suffers a bit from being too long and repeating itself, but a surprisingly fun ride throughout.

Name: The Last House on the Left
Review:
a) are the weird happy-go-lucky songs in the first half supposed to cause unease? to give the impression that the film is on the side of the killers?

b) is the wacky journey of the cops supposed to imply that law enforcement is incompetent and give a "take matters into yr own hands" message, a la DEATH WISH?

maybe they're both right, but I have trouble putting together these undercurrents with the film I actually watched.

Name: The Death King
Review: low budget morbid curiosity from early 90s germany that plays like an art house FACES OF DEATH. seven segments featuring suicides and/or murders. the penultimate is legitately disturbing and most memorable, but it takes a while to get there. there's also a repeating interlude of a decaying corpse which would be a good companion to that one Brakhage film.

Name: Point Break
Review: I don't understand swayze's appeal

Name: WNUF Halloween Special
Review: I love the effort that went into presenting this as a real artifact, especially the segments/commercials that are included purely to invoke the mood of the times.

Name: The Fly II
Review: why this wasn't called "son of the fly" is beyond me

Name: Dracula
Review: I am absolutely Here For This

Name: Children of the Corn
Review: the kids' fashion is pretty great. so there's that I guess.

Name: Detour
Review: ann savage <3 <3

Name: Fatal Honeymoon
Review: this may very well be my favorite harvey keitel performance? more harvey playing normal old dudes please.

Name: Alien Intrusion: Unmasking a Deception
Review: spoiler: aliens are demons

Name: Passenger 57
Review: a showcase of 90s action tropes and a fantastic slap-bass/saxophone soundtrack.

Name: The Conjuring
Review: there's a fantastic haunted house movie in there that's unfortunately bogged down with too much going on. not really sure the warrens needed to be major characters. but james wan knows how to direct the hell out of a slow scare (that is, when the camera isn't flailing around).

Name: Tank
Review: a fun, odd movie about family, a tank, and posse comitatus. definitely 30 mins too long, but it's easy to get swept up in how much fun everyone seems to be having.

Name: Annihilation
Review: probably gonna need to see this one again. it wasn't an unpleasant "what's going on here? / i think i know what's going on", but i still feel uncertain

Name: The Dark Knight
Review: every time I rewatch this, the convoluted-ness of the plot is more apparent. I still cry at just about every Michael Caine speech though.

Name: The Dark Knight Rises
Review: maybe it's because no one i watched this with was having it, but this didn't hold up very strongly. everything's muddy because there's too much of it happening. remember how great the trailers were in the lead-up to its release?

Name: The Nice Guys
Review: one of my favorite screenplays in recent memory and everyone knocks it out of the park.

Name: The Craft
Review: when nancy's stepfather/mom's-boyfriend dies, they get $175k from his insurance. with that they buy: a jukebox of connie frances records, new furniture + outfits, a convertable, and move to a fancy 2(?) bedroom apartment in la. a) did they buy or rent the apt? b) of renting, how long can they expect to live there?

Name: Five Easy Pieces
Review: i spent a majority of the movie not liking bobby before i realized that neither does he. it's fascinating and beautiful and poignant in a way that feels very of its time.

Name: Decasia
Review: dizzying and fascinating. there's a sequence early on that, from the dissonant soundtrack and slowed frame-rate, creeped me out like a great horror film. the score is like a dream penderecki / godspeed you black emperor collab.

Name: Benny's Video
Review: this plays out like a literal nightmare, which makes it unforgettable. the messaging of the movie is a little heavy-handed, which is kinda haneke's thing.

Name: Voyage to the Sky
Review: some lovely special effects in this, and a surprisingly understandable explanation of how distance in space is calculated.

Name: Light Is Calling
Review: the yellowing and warping of the filmstock give the feeling of human forms emerging from flames.

Name: Unsane
Review: this movie succeeds when it's left ambiguous, and the back half suffers when the jig is up, so to speak. there's also some subplots that are a little heavy handed. and a totally unnecessary cameo.

Name: Andre the Giant
Review: a fine watch, but plays out almost exactly how you'd imagine it would. almost unfortunately conventional in its approach.

Name: Se7en
Review: woof. not having seen this in years, the memory that sticks is mostly how grisly the crime scenes are. but the crushing hopelessness that permeates is stronger now.

Name: Eraserhead
Review: encompasses every anxiety i have about becoming an adult

Name: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
Review: i was shook for a solid fifteen minutes after the credits finished. the plot was mentioned to me long enough ago that i had forgotten the broad strokes + went in mostly not knowing what to expect. that seems like the best way to take this one in. i'd love to read the screenplay. (also, i completely missed alicia silverstone)

Name: In Search of Ozu
Review: a nice look at pieces of ozu's life/career. definitely fine as an extra feature. i could watch a whole film / read a whole book discussinf his screenplays and storyboards.

Name: Out of the Past
Review: lots of twists and turns, which isnt the easiest to follow on an airplane. can't lie, i had a hard time telling kathie and carson (the secretary) apart. kirk douglas is wonderfully sleazy. would have loved to see a non-code version where jeff and kathie get away together but despise each other.

Name: My Winnipeg
Review: a mythical documentary loveletter fantasy of a film. hints of lynch, von trier, and gilliam somehow? really made me feel like i know nothing about the area i've lived in my whole life.

Name: The Devils
Review: to be honest, i spent a good portion of the first half not quite sure of what was happening. once the machinations became clear, however, it was hard to look away. the score is unnerving and unrelenting at times, and a few of the sequences in the back half were anxiety-inducing.  yikes.

Name: Groundhog Day
Review: i was expecting the game of the movie to be spoiled by how embedded it's become in pop culture, but it still feels fresh and exciting. some of the editng choices are really nice and capture the infinite loop feeling super well. i'm glad i finally saw this as an adult; i'm sure a lot of it would have been lost (or unappreciated) on a younger me.

Name: Stripes
Review: there were a couple of decent gags early on, but not from the main cast. i don't think comedies from this era really hold up, and this is no exception. i found it tedious and forgettable.

Name: GoodFellas
Review: always love to see this and be reminded of how many references to it in my day-to-day.

Name: Casino
Review: the sunglasses just keep getting bigger and bigger as the film progresses

Name: A Quiet Place
Review: Some pretty effective scenes and the quiet parts live up to the hype. It goes a little overboard on the *VOLUME TO TEN* scares which just becomes tired by the end. The monsters are also meh; yadda yadda the horror is what isn't seen. I was super glad to see that the newscasts that open up one of the trailers aren't included.

Name: Skate Witches
Review: as with PUCE MOMENT and DIRTY GIRLS, i feel like things might have turned out differently for me if i saw this in high school. short, sweet, tuff, funny, weird, perfect.

Name: Manson's Lost Girls
Review: all of the men are hillariously miscast. and really, everyone looks like a model. we spent most of the time discussing what a Good Manson Film would be like. that being said, it gets better as it progresses and ends up with a few good sequences. for a lifetime movie, it does a pretty good job.

Name: Re-Animator
Review: delightfully bonkers.

Name: Return of the Living Dead Part II
Review: enjoyable when the jokes land but kind of a slog otherwise. i do love the idea of bringing back characters who died a movie previously and not addressing it.

Name: Pet Sematary
Review: next verse, same as the first: fred gwynne is the reason to return to this. the rest of the cast plays it like a made-for-tv movie. but like, use jud's speeches for an acting audition; they're great.

Name: Tales from the Crypt
Review: this is just a fun trip, very faithful in vibe to the comics, from what i remember. makes me want to marathon horror anthologies from the period.

Name: Zombie Flesh Eaters
Review: grows on me each time. a high-water mark for italian zombie pictures.

Name: Black Magic Part II
Review: final reel was missing, but i still need to see this again just to try to figure out what the hell is going on.

Name: The Alphabet
Review: the thought of lynch making this in a tiny apartment in philadelphia fills me with joy and wonder.

Name: Altered States
Review: in a nice twist, i enjoyed this a whole lot more than i did whenever it was i first saw it. incredible compositions, eerie/cacophonous score. the dialogue is almost impossible to follow at times, however: people yelling smart things over each other at a breakneck pace. (according to imdb trivia: intentionally hard to understand as a protest against the material?) i also have no concrete idea of what is going on? what a weird horror movie.

Name: Halloween
Review: beat-up print at the drive-in is a great way to see this.

Name: Prince of Darkness
Review: i found this to be incredibly incomprehensible to the point where i sat slackjawed trying to understand what anyone was saying. it's a jumbled hodgepodge of ideas encountered by something like 8 characters who have no idea what is happening. maybe i need to watch it alone where i'm able to rewind. there are some interesting images/concepts in the backhalf but by that point i was gone.

Name: Christine
Review: as terrible as the concept of an evil car sounds, this manages to pull it off pretty well.

Name: In the Mouth of Madness
Review: kind of like a lovecraftian noir which is an interesting idea. all of the driving scenes really got me, as did the dream sequence with the cop. the scenes with sutter cane are a little much but i'm on board all the way down.

Name: Peeping Tom
Review: has the grimy feel of an american film of the 70s.  super interesting to see this executed in 1960

Name: Enter the Dragon
Review: i wonder if a lot of the reputation around this movie has to do with bruce lee's death during post-production. it's a fine watch, definitely a good first classic martial arts film, but there weren't any moments that felt as revelatory as i was expecting with its notoriety.

Name: My Cousin Vinny
Review: an all-around Very Good 90s comedy. the laughs still land for me, even after watching this all the time on cable in my early 20s. marissa tomei deserved her oscar. i'll always pop for fred gwynne. if i have a complaint, it's that vinny's courtroom prowess seems unearned. there could've been more than just a montage to show that he has his shit together.

Name: Boy Meets Girl
Review:
this was a very nice watch. its independent-ness shows at times (the film would have benefitted from more post-production work, especially some of the color timing and foley work) but it adds to the film's charm. the writing feels true most of the time and the dialogue is more vulgar (read: "real") than i was expecting. that being said, the characters seem to have odd boundaries with some of the topics, which i can't tell is true to the characters or the writer getting to a certain point and then pulling back ("no that's too far!"). for some of the characters it feels a bit jarring for them to be prudish, but then again, that's how some people are.

also, not to spoil anything, but a character has a shift in the last act that feels a little out of place and just kind of... there? maybe unearned? i don't know; the scene where it happens also just feels a little oddly placed in the story. 

anyway, it's a good watch. a mature look at a story that could have been super watered-down in a not-good Lifetime way. michelle hendley is fantastic in her first role (?!)

Name: Hereditary
Review: it's every bit as good as the trailer made it seem and then some. legit terrifying.

Name: The Room
Review: they're all in hell, right? like, every character is trapped in a hell where time has no meaning and they keep trying to exit but no one can get away.

Name: Hereditary
Review: it's still fucking great. seeing it again so shortly after the first time made me aware of how i watch films initially. like how easily i get sucked into a story and miss small moments/details; how willing i am to go along for the ride. this one got me and is likely to continue getting me. the second time around was a lot clearer-eyed and let me enjoy the craft of the film, which is exceptional for a first-timer.

Name: Police Story
Review: nobody does an action set piece like jackie chan. some jokes/gags haven't aged well, but a fun trip overall.

Name: The Disaster Artist
Review: did this need to get made? it had the feel of a funny or die sketch that went on for way too long. maybe a shot-for-shot remake á la van sant's PSYCHO would've conveyed the same love of the source material without mythologizing the original. or even a documentary. to me, that's when this film really shined.

Name: Upgrade
Review:
i'll give it props for looking like a much larger budgeted film. you really can do a lot with cgi for not a lot of money.

the score is also a really nice warm synth bath at times.

Name: From Dusk Till Dawn
Review: this is great any time tarantino isn't on screen. i'd watch the shit out of a bergman-esque film w/ keitel's character

Name: Near Dark
Review: i had to let this one sink in a bit but i think i really dug it. it shares a vibe with my favorite 80s b-movies which i can't explain too well: the story is tight and works within its tight budget super well.

Name: 2001: A Space Odyssey
Review: fulfilled a life goal of seeing this on 70mm. you really notice the difference with the effects work. the sound was also maybe a notch too high which was perfect for the most part (some parts of BEYOND THE INFINITE had some distortion).

Name: 2001: A Space Odyssey
Review: seeing this with an actual intermission, the scenes following could be drawn out a bit more.

Name: Dunkirk
Review: i really messed up by not seeing this in a theater

Name: Raiders of the Lost Ark
Review: somehow i remembered indy being double-crossed a whole lot.

Name: A Serbian Film
Review: yep, it's as bleak/vile/fucked as you've heard. i wasn't expecting it to look as slick as it does.

Name: The Purge
Review: completely forgot i watched this a year ago. it's still "meh".

Name: The Belko Experiment
Review: of course i missed 10 minutes in the middle when things go down, but i still found it enjoyable and darkly fun. kind of reminded me of CABIN IN THE WOODS?

Name: The Asphalt Jungle
Review: everything's firing on all cylinders. sterling hayden, good lord. if i have a complaint, it's that it keeps going, but i'm hard-pressed to think of what could go. the last 15-20 minutes are heart-breaking. is john huston just the best at doing noir flicks?
half of this movie takes place in lighting so low that it's impossible to see anything. it's also a procedural? the acting is community theater level but that's the charm.

Name: Ozone
Review: the physical effects are shockingly good. and there's a great "achy-breaky heart" parody.

Name: Hack-O-Lantern
Review: there's a lot about this that's incomprehensible but that doesn't stop it from being trashy fun. the out-of-the-blue music video rules.

Name: The Slumber Party Massacre
Review: apparently this was written as a parody but shot straight, which both makes sense and helped get me through some of the laggy bits.

Name: The Fourth Kind
Review:
i think i liked this more than i did whenever it was that i first saw it. it's a real disappointment that the entire thing is made up, but on that note, the woman who plays the "real" abigail tyler (charlotte milchard) is great and i wish she had a larger resume. 

i do wish the cross-cutting between the "re-enactments" and "archival footage" was done in a more straight-forward way. osunsanmi plays out some scenes in a distracting split-screen (sometimes 4 panel) way that's remniscient of de palma but is wholy inappropriate for the film it's trying to be.

Name: Burroughs: The Movie
Review: burroughs was a lot sweeter than i had imagined. a nice peek into the life of an infamous dude.

Name: Choke
Review:
yowza. trying to explain the twists in this movie made me appreciate it a whole lot more than actually watching it. i'll say this, it looks like dennis hopper and michael madsen had a lot of fun shooting this. at least, i hope they did. 

i think a good 60% of this is dennis hopper looking around a room processing information while his internal monologue spells it out for the audience. it's bonkers. so much of this is superfluous: the flash-forwards, the flashbacks, the peeping Tom eavesdropper, the stoner hitchhikers. 

maybe watch this as a triple feature with SPEED and RESERVOIR DOGS and order a pizza and have a good time.

Name: Tourist Trap
Review: this was such a weird/wild trip and i had fun the whole way through. the first kill segment is one of my favorites.

Name: Sorry to Bother You
Review:
i'm having trouble putting words to my feelings. i adored the script and i'm so glad that everything was kept. it's super well put together and if i had a complaint it's a little uneven in its editing (i think the film works better when things are allowed to linger a bit).

liam put it perfectly: "Is it an angry joke or is it a story so upsetting you HAVE to laugh?"

Name: Daughters of Darkness
Review: i loved this one. it's weird and slow and disjointed and i have a lot of questions but it got its hooks into me and i was all-in for the journey.

Name: Robin Williams: Come Inside My Mind
Review: a very nice doc but felt incomplete. almost the entirety of the 90s is skipped over, which may have been noticeable only because that's the period of time that's most familiar to me. but some very good/nice interviews and variety of footage.

Name: Hype!
Review: this does a great job at making the seattle scene seem like a ton of fun. got me nostalgic for being in a band.

Name: Downrange
Review: an interesting concept that is stretched thin by maybe 20 minutes. the film works best when the sense of danger is unrelenting, which it loses a bit in the middle. some fantastic make-up in this, and it's one bit stunt setpiece was suprisingly thrilling. i could have done without the superfluous shots of the shooter and an unneccessarily cruel twist ending.

Name: Sleepaway Camp
Review: it's always a treat to watch this. this might be the first time that all the pieces really came together for me.

Name: mother!
Review: i'm glad someone finally made a movie about how i feel at parties

Name: Won't You Be My Neighbor?
Review: based solely on how much i cried during the trailer, i (correctly) figured i'd be a wreck during this. but what was unexpected was how hopeful i felt leaving the theater. it's a beautiful and necessary piece of cinema.

Name: Burnt Offerings
Review: a 70s slow-burn that's got a weird air and lots of soft focus / vaseline'd lenses. the acting's kinda all over the board; not sure how i feel about oliver reed. i'm starting to get a taste for haunted house movies.

Name: I Bury the Living
Review: shave 20 minutes off and this is a perfect hour-long episode of the twilight zone. the thesis of the movie is good enough to make up for the extended pin-pushing sequences. it's almost my ideal 50s b-movie.

Name: Carnival of Souls
Review: a thick fog rolled in for about a solid third of the film, which was appropriate but also made most of what happened incomprehensible. i love a movie with a bare premise that pads out the runtime with atmosphere.

Name: Backwoods Marcy
Review:
this isn't a good film. like at all. yet it's fascinating as a kind-of feminist take on films like I SPIT ON YOUR GRAVE. well, the front half of movie is like that. dude's lost driving in the backwoods (for, no joke, the first third of the film). encounters the titular character, gets held captive + raped, then escapes. is this video art? i'd love to hear the writer talk about her intentions.

also, there's some awful late-90s edm that's incessantly throughout. again, this isnt a good film.

Name: Dementia 13
Review: is this a proto-giallo? super watchable and fun and only lags a bit towards the end. the first 20 mins are solid.

Name: The Slime People
Review: about 2/3rds of this is shrouded in fog

Name: The Descent
Review: i was all in until the monsters showed up.

Name: As Above, So Below
Review: would it be better if there weren't any good parts? if this was just dumb out of the gate and stayed that way? there are some tantalizingly good moments in here that are forced to exist along "here's another well. guess we'll keep going down!"

Name: What We Do in the Shadows
Review: the performances are top notch and the effects are surprisingly effective for what i would assume is a lower budget film.

Name: Quiet Zone
Review: achingly sad interviews with women who suffer from electrical sensitivity played to decayed/warped film á la bill morrison. really beautifully made.
Tags: streaming, national film board of canada

Name: Pieces
Review: it's just as bonkers as i remembered. the gore is well done, but you spend a lot of the down-time trying to figure out what's happening, which some details/scenes don't make easy. it's a good second movie with a group, after a few drinks and maybe a legitimately good opener.

Name: Before Sunrise
Review: i bet ethan hawke's character has some strong opinions on tipping.

Name: Three Identical Strangers
Review: the pacing is great, but the open ending (not the fault of the film) can't help but feel incomplete. a wild trip.

Name: Possession
Review: a frenzied fever dream of a movie. i was dizzy trying to figure out what was happening but adored every minute of it. so many of the dialogue scenes are yelled in echo-y rooms with thick european accents, so i understood maybe a third of what was said, which just added to the fogginess. absolutely unlike anything i've ever seen before.

Name: Barry Lyndon
Review: this was a treat to watch. the story is more enjoyable than i remember, but the actual production of everything is incredible.

Name: Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2
Review:
it's fun in a schlocky late-90s way, just keep your expectations super low. there are some interesting ideas in here, but the whole thing was clearly slapped together as quick as possible to capitalize on the first film. 

also, shudder had this squeezed into a 1:66 frame (instead of 1:85) and i started thinking about how nice it would be to not notice stuff like that.

"fuckin' witch!"

Name: Demons 2
Review: dumb and gory and fun

Name: Angst
Review: incredible camerawork and a cute dachschund. the narration lost me, though.

Name: Friday the 13th Part 2
Review: you ever watch a movie so much that you start dinging it for some of the lens choices the dp/director made?

Name: My Bloody Valentine
Review:
there are some really charming canadian accents and some overacting that almost make up for the lagging pacing in the back half. 

the print was beat-up but distractingly so. also, i missed the first 5 minutes and was getting tired, so maybe i'd enjoy this more on video. or not starting it at 11.

Name: The 36th Chamber of Shaolin
Review: it's so good. i definitely would've watched at least 5 more chambers.

Name: Jaws
Review: i remembered this slogging in the middle more than it actually does; this might have been the first time i Really Watched it. the jump between the shark cage sequence and the final one feels weirdly truncated for a movie that likes to let things breathe. whatever; i saw this in a theater of fans that popped at the right parts and watched lauren scramble up her seat at all the jump scares (she'd never seen it before).

Name: Video Voyeur: The Susan Wilson Story
Review: next to MY NAME IS SARAH, maybe my ideal lifetime movie? angie harmon is fantastic and dale midkiff actually seems appropriate (unlike in PET SEMATARY, which is the only other thing i've seen him in). the back half deals with susan's trauma which harmon makes more upsetting. a very decent watch.

Name: Terrifier
Review:
it's fine; it's a creepy clown running around killing people in a warehouse. there's some decent make-up effects for what i'm assuming was a pretty low budget. and the clown in a pizza joint's lighting is effective. but most of the film is an exercise in run-of-the-mill torture porn. to be fair though, i don't think it's trying to be anything more, and i'm grateful for that. 

looking back, i apparently gave ALL HALLOW'S EVE, art the clown's introduction, 3 stars which is more than kind. i liked this better, but it's still just fine.

Name: VHS Massacre: Cult Films and the Decline of Physical Media
Review: some of the interviews are good (i love joe bob briggs when he's not drifting into adam carolla material) but unfortunately it's nothing special. has me regretting giving away my vhs tapes when i moved, though.

Name: My Husband's Secret Wife
Review: there are some lifetime movies that are super enjoyable when they're incomprehensible, but this is unfortunately not one of them. we had a lot of "wait, what??" moments, but not the good kind.

Name: Invasion of the Body Snatchers
Review: wow. it's a perfect remake for its time. the visual language is a great combination of very 70s zooms + 50s b-movie angles and shadows. the paranoia is palpable.

Name: The Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call - New Orleans
Review: shoot him again, his soul's still dancing

Name: Mandy
Review: strange and beautiful and wild and over-the-top. the soundtrack is phenomenal and you've really got to see this one in a theater.

Name: Blow-Up
Review: the best parts, for me, are when things settle down and the soundtrack is just the sound of wind through trees.

Name: Spacehunter: Adventures in the Forbidden Zone
Review: the budget seems surprisingly high, even though the sets/effects are all meh. imagine an alternate universe where STAR WARS wasn't a success or loved, but george lucas made the sequels anyway and was heavily influenced by seeing MAD MAX once.

Name: The King of Comedy
Review: some real cringey parts in the first half. and in rupert's act. okay, the whole thing made me squirm.

Name: Army of Darkness
Review: i forgot how much fun this one is. i think i prefer the two EVIL DEAD films, but it's still a heck of a run.

Name: Big Driver
Review: does a good stephen king adaptation require the original story to be good? because i haven't read this one but the movie is legit Very Good. it loses some of the momentum towards the end and wraps up neatly (maybe the most on-the-nose sign that this is a lifetime stephen king adaptation), but the ride there was harrowing and well-done.

Name: Terror
Review: lauren described this as "violently [my] shit", which is a perfect assessment. assembled with love (some of the films featured are deep-cuts). i cheered when the "hello?" montage began.

Name: Alice Sweet Alice
Review: very watchable with some american giallo vibes. i was kind of expecting a supernatural twist to come up, but it never did. the kills are surprisingly visceral and the whole thing has a layer of grime on it. it's great.

Name: The Night of a Thousand Cats
Review:
what a weird and fun film. this seems like the product of an all-night bender and the director or star having access to a helicopter for the weekend. do you like various forms of transportation? you'll be in for a treat! love seeing cats thrown around? check this one out!

we watched the 62 minute cut and had a blast. i wonder if the longer 90+ minute version is as much fun.

Name: Contamination
Review: according to imdb, part of the funding for this was provided by columbian drug lords, which i'm suspecting is why a third of the movie acts as a sort-of south american travelogue. the effects are cool, but in reality it's the same chest-exploding effect used on about a dozen extras.

Name: The Boy
Review: i was with this until the last 20 minutes or so. the idea is refreshingly unique and weird and i was happy to go along for the ride.

Name: Nightmare City
Review: this has enough going for it (terrible make-up, unique zombie traits, a wtf ending) that it becomes more memorable than your run-of-the-mill euro-zombie (yeah i know these aren't really "zombies") film from the 70s/80s. i think there's like 4 or 5 shots of creatures wiping blood off their mouth in a dramatic fashion and it got a laugh every time.

Name: The Seventh Seal
Review: i guess it's been a minute since i've seen this last. i forgot how much humor is in the script; the lasting memory is of max von sydow brooding while looking great. gunnar björnstrand is the standout, though.

Name: De Düva: The Dove
Review: i lost it once i realized they were speaking fake sweedish

Name: Bill & Ted's Bogus Journey
Review:
i think i've only seen this in chunks on tv as a kid? it plays fantastically with an audience -- the games-with-death sequence was longer and funnier than i remembered. 

also, fashion in the 26th(?) century is awesome.

Name: The Gore Gore Girls
Review: a midwestern giallo that's also kind of a comedy? it seems like it was a lot of fun to make, which goes a long way.

Name: Mausoleum
Review:
this was a trip. it's hammy and corny and sorta-gory and weird. i don't think i've seen this one talked about much, which is a shame. it's a great second/third tier demon film from the eighties. 

also, can we talk about the colors/lighting choices? iconic.

Name: Black Sabbath
Review: the visuals are gorgeous to look at. and the third story is great. i could've sworn the middle segment was longer than a half hour.

Name: The Wizard of Gore
Review: i love a movie that makes zero sense and shrugs its shoulders at the end saying "it's impossible!" it's got all the staples of an hgl film with the added bonus of playing with reality to make it extra bonkers.

Name: Mark of the Witch
Review: it's campy and fun. anitra walsh is great.  i haven't seen THE LOVE WITCH yet but this reminds me of the trailer. lush colors all around.

Name: The Screaming Skull
Review: i'd only seen this in its mst3k incarnation, which leads to assumptions of mediocrity. but it's pretty watchable. the ending is goofy. but the atmosphere it builds up is pretty nice.

Name: Asylum
Review: i thought the first two stories (the voodoo one and the tailor one) were the strongest. not as overall enjoyable as TALES FROM THE CRYPT, my only other amicus point of comparison.

Name: Sleepaway Camp II: Unhappy Campers
Review: it's a lot of fun when it's not getting into the semantics of angela's backstory (it's the late 80s, so the queer-phobic language isn't much of a surprise, it's just exhausting). renée estevez is charming and pamela springsteen is clearly having a blast.

Name: Lisa and the Devil
Review: beautiful to watch, but i had a hard time keeping up with the story (according to the wiki, a train passed by during an important plot reveal). the (sorta) dream logic works so good with bava's style, so i wasn't completely out-to-sea.

Name: Double Trouble
Review: it's a kids movie but for adults. some good one-liners sprinkled throughout but i'm not sure how this plays without a crowd/group of friends.

Name: Sleepaway Camp III: Teenage Wasteland
Review:
in theory, angela is only killing people as a form of punishment, but since pretty much everyone is awful, does it really matter? parts 2 and 3 might be my favorite slasher sequels solely because they don't bother to try to flesh out the killer. they're how people describe the later NIGHTMAREs and FRIDAY/13ths. the cut i saw had a lot of the gore edited out, which raises the question of why one would watch this in that case. 

there's some late 80s racism/classism throughout that's super offputting, but for a series whose first entry includes jokes about pedophilia, you kinda know what you're in for by this point.

Name: Ænigma
Review:
some parts (namely the stuff around kathy) seem to be tacked onto another film about a bitchy psychokinetic new-girl. and the first half doesn't feel like a fulci film at all.

wasn't really worth the effort you have to put in to figure out what adult figure is sleeping with a student.

Name: The Marine
Review: this is an film that was Actually Made and was Actually Shown In Theaters.

Name: The Witch Who Came from the Sea
Review: i want to see this again after a little time passes. there's a lot of playing with reality that i had a hard time keeping up with

Name: Satan
Review: it's a turkish scene-for-scene remake of THE EXORCIST that's a fascinating watch. there's zero budget, and the theme from the original is looped and likely stolen. the effects are cheap and the acting's flat. this was super enjoyable as a two-person watch and would probably be great at a party.

Name: The Visit
Review: way better than i was expecting. the casting is fantastic. one of the better found-footage jawns.

Name: Night of the Demons
Review: my kingdom for stooge's BORN TO BURN devil shirt.

Name: [REC]
Review: a hell of a trip... until the last 10 minutes when it tries squeezing a mythology into the story (which seems like a common flaw in found-footage films). some solid gore and creepy vibes throughout.

Name: Paranormal Activity
Review: apparently spielberg saw a screener and suggested the current ending, which is easily the weakest part. i would have loved to have seen this opening weekend with a packed house.

Name: She Demons
Review: some real cornball stuff here

Name: The War of the Worlds
Review: it’s some good, if higher budgeted, clean sci-fi fun until the conclusion, which is a bummer cop out

Name: Alien
Review: was shocked to see the director’s cut on 35mm, but i guess it checks out?

Name: The Blob
Review: i think i drifted off a bit towards the end (in my defense, it was like 530a), but the effects are so good.

Name: Without Warning
Review: i feel so blessed to have seen this on film twice within a year

Name: Killer Klowns from Outer Space
Review: i have vivid memories of this always being on the sci-fi channel and the image of corpses in cotton candy haunting me. it’s also goofy as hell.

Name: The Deadly Spawn
Review: this is nuts

Name: Village of the Damned
Review: there are times where this feels like a 90s tv movie, which is a bummer. but there are some pretty good nuggets in here.

Name: Halloween
Review: it’s definitely at the head of the pack as far as franchise sequels go. and brutal in a “you want blood and guts? okay, this shit isn’t pretty” kind of way. but also kinda disjointed? i wanted to see laurie stroud’s world a lot more than her granddaughter’s.

Name: Body Melt
Review: there’s only a few melts (everyone else kinda explodes or has weird growths). the soundtrack is a solid 70 minutes of techno

Name: Jennifer's Body
Review: at least there’s a good stoner metal track?

Name: The Wicker Man
Review: lauren described it as a horror movie to just one character, which is perfect. this makes so much more sense than (what i remember of) the remake.

Name: They'll Love Me When I'm Dead
Review: i really need to see more orson welles films

Name: The Final Terror
Review: totally fine / serviceable slasher flick. it’s shot pretty nicely for what seems like a real cheap production. come for the fake james woods, stay for the thick accents (american southern, and british??)

Name: Fahrenheit 9/11
Review:
“there clearly is no way that anyone can live constantly on edge like that” 

fast-forward 14 years 😅

Name: Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2
Review: watched a fan edit which claims to be closer to the director’s intentions. the pacing is definitely improved (something like 10 minutes were shaved off) and there’s clearly a message this time around.

Name: Suspiria
Review: gorgeously made and, i think, easier to follow than the original. still had A Time making sense of what was going on in parts, but in a Good Way.

Name: Hereditary
Review: i’m really curious to know what was changed as a result of audience testing (if anything). in particular, ann dowd’s voice-over at the end. i don’t have a problem with it (i’m not too well-versed in my kings of hell), but it definitely feels like it gives up some of the ambiguity the film has throughout.

Name: Filmworker
Review: did we need another film relating how kubrick was a genius but also worked himself and everyone around him to their ragged edge? probably not. did we need a film about leon vitali? turns out we absolutely did.

Name: The Black Cat
Review: i wish i saw this with english dubbing because patrick mcgee’s voice is so great/distinct/weird.

Name: All She Wants for Christmas
Review: definitely in so-bad-it’s-good territory. the twist is clear about 5 minutes in. there’s a scene where an extra in the background slips and falls and the rest of the extras all stop and stare and that’s the take they kept. i want to watch again and just focus on the action in the background.

Name: Sinister Minister
Review: it starts out okay but then nosedives into mediocrity. nikki howard is better than the script she was given.

Name: Cyborg 2
Review: this might be the most incomprehensible movie i’ve ever seen. at least jack parlance seems like he had a good time the two days he was on set.

Name: The Spirit of Christmas
Review: never thought a christmas movie about a no-nonsense lady falling in love with a ghost could be this dull and yet...

Name: The Texas Chain Saw Massacre
Review: “look what your brother did to the door!”

Name: The Hills Have Eyes
Review: wes almost made it through the whole movie without a booby trap. almost.

Name: Blood Rage
Review: they really used every second of footage they got of louise lasser, didn’t they? it gets an extra half star for the ending.

Name: Dead or Alive
Review: like someone’s acid-influenced rememberance of HEAT with a lot more gross-out sequences.

Name: You Were Never Really Here
Review: woof. this is a heavy trip.

Name: Electric Boogaloo: The Wild, Untold Story of Cannon Films
Review: really charming history of a company whose reputation precedes it.

Name: Opera
Review:
what’s the deal with the music? there’s only opera in the first thirty minutes and all of a sudden a metal track during a murder. and occasionlly a random child-sung melody. i have no idea. 

the camerawork is fantastic. it’s a shame steadicams came to prominence after the giallo heyday.

Name: The Zodiac Killer
Review: a whole lot of schlocky goodness

Name: Stalked by My Doctor
Review: i want to believe that eric roberts was/is a ton of fun to be around on set

Name: The Boneyard
Review: not funny enough to work as a comedy but too goofy to work as straight horror. the creature effects are pretty good. deborah rose gives a lot more than the movie deserves and it’s a bummer this is her last role.

Name: Never Take Sweets from a Stranger
Review: surprisingly frank and upsetting without resorting to exploitation. the dude playing the junior olderberry is effectively slimey.

Name: Lost Holiday: The Jim & Suzanne Shemwell Story
Review: no one seems too distraught that the parents are missing on a mountain until maybe the third day.

Name: Happy Birthday to Me
Review: an enjoyable canadian giallo/slasher flick that holds up until the twist in the last 10 minutes. the ending i was expecting was a stretch but jeez louise is the actual one really reaching.

Name: Grizzly
Review: well-paced until the last reel with some “grizzly” deaths popping up whenever the plot starts to lag. if you couldn’t relate to JAWS because you’re landlocked, this might be a suitable alternative.

Name: Maniac
Review: wonderfully grimy and squirm-inducing, mainly by joe spinell’s performance both on-screen and off (his breathing + moaning on the soundtrack is Rough). great early slasher.

Name: Creepshow 2
Review: maybe it works better with a crowd, but i didn’t really like this at all. the second story started strong but the ending was weak. and the third story seems like it would work better on the page. meh.

Name: Document of the Dead
Review: overall it’s really interesting to see george romero over the course of like 20 years. it’s all over the place, which is kind of a bummer, and the back half is mostly fans/friends heaping praise (though his daughter has some wonderful anecdotes). but the behind the scenes footage of DAWN OF THE DEAD is worth the price of admission alone.

Name: Another Son of Sam
Review:
the first half is a smorgasbord of fascinating film-making decisions but it gets bogged down stretching out a ten minute finale into something like twenty-five. 

they really got their money’s worth with that johnny charro song.

Name: Beyond the Door
Review: i think i liked this? it has some of the usual pitfalls you’d expect (a WHOLE lot of walking around and talking) but there’s enough weird nuggets throughout to be entertaining.

Name: The Legend of Boggy Creek
Review: immediately flooded my brain with memories of THE TOWN THAT DREADED SUNDOWN. i really like pierce’s faux(?)-documentary style in these two films and the touch of having people star in reenactments is a lot of fun. the pacing is all over the place and really languid at times, but again, it just adds to the overall mood.

Name: Shirkers
Review: one of those great ones that inspires from the outset, before the main story even takes place. and then the main thrust kicks in and your jaw hits the floor. the craft of the filmmaking belies sandi tan's short (filmmaking) resume. this is a film by someone who was born to make them. it's joyous, painful, funny, sad, nostalgic, infuriating, and beautiful.

Name: The Clovehitch Killer
Review: that didn’t play out at all like i was expecting. well-crafted and superbly acted. loved it.

Name: Road to Revenge
Review: absolutely fascinating passion project. one of the actors does a crazed dennis hopper impression the whole time. i’m always here for this.

Name: Better Watch Out
Review: eli roth fans remaking FUNNY GAMES as a black comedy and shooting for a soft R.

Name: Blood Hook
Review: it's charming and fun until it becomes a bit of a slog. i'm a sucker for midwest accents, so all of the locals really get me. however, there's a significant drop in energy whenever the peter character is on screen (it doesn't help that the actor looks like karen's asshole/creep neighbor from GOODFELLAS).

Name: Spine Tingler! The William Castle Story
Review: this was just nice

Name: Christmas Evil
Review: all of the wood panelling and drop ceilings got me feeling feels.

Name: Nancy
Review: i’m always here for sad movies about sad people but this was exceptional.

Name: Bombshell
Review:
so enjoyable and charming.


 “step on it cabbie, i’m being annoyed!”

Name: All the President's Men
Review: those opening thirty minutes, good gravy. hoffman + redford are so good, but how about that supporting cast?

Name: Eyes Wide Shut
Review: this was my first time watching with a crowd (i’ve apparently only watched this by myself the dozen or so times in the past?) and first in a theater. the humor comes out a lot clearer with other people around. it’s got some strange logic and you get the feeling that kubrick would have trimmed some of the fat had he lived. still beautiful and weird and unique and great. maybe the best viewing i’ve had yet.

Name: Cam
Review: i’m so glad that the cam site wasn’t a law-and-order-esque copy but actually believable.

Name: Phantasm
Review: i think i wasn’t actively seeking this one out because any synopsis i would read just made it sound preposterous and uninteresting. yet here i am ready to invest in the whole kitten-kaboodle after a single viewing. the logic is all over the place but i guess but that’s intentional? it’s a blessing that this doesn’t get boring. into it.

Name: Lost Soul: The Doomed Journey of Richard Stanley's Island of Dr. Moreau
Review: i completely forgot i watched this a couple hours after the fact. it’s fine, but limps along after richard stanley’s firing.

Name: Nightbreed
Review: maybe this would work better as a comic book? i dunno; this definitely wasn’t for me.

Name: Vice
Review: adam mckay’s getting really close to finding that sweet spot as a filmmaker between michael moore and 90’s oliver stone. tonally, it’s all over the place, and some of the comedic moments weigh it down. but the performances are all fantastic and i think the cross-cutting works. this is the kind of film i was hoping for when W came out forever ago.

Name: Misery
Review:
it’s an exercise in spot-on storytelling in a film. there’s no excess here; everything is in its place and serves its purpose. also, the make-up!

a bone to pick: stephen king’s big complaint about THE SHINING is that the subtext of fatherhood/alcoholism is stripped out. but this completely removes the annie-as-stand-in-for-addiction subtext and yet he’s not out there giving some convoluted car metaphor about it. 


(clearly i’m incensed about this)

Name: A Simple Favor
Review:
i dunno, this was so hard to get through. everyone is insufferable and smug. and what the hell is up with the french soundtrack?

there’s a trio of parents that saves this from being a complete disaster, but only slightly. no thanks.

Name: Duck Soup
Review: enjoyable but a bit too scattered for my taste?

Name: Room Service
Review: i like the idea of keeping the action mostly in a single location. the supporting cast really sold this one for me.

Name: Monkey Business
Review: the part with chico at the piano really got me

Name: A Night at the Opera
Review: what an absolute delight
